metadata.title: Noble-metal-free NiFe nanoparticles immobilized on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions for highly efficient hydrogen production from hydrous hydrazine

ARTICLE

Institute of Advanced Materials (IAM), College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang 330022, P.R. China. Email: luzh@jxnu.edu.cn † Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI) available. See DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
Received 00th January 20xx, Accepted 00th January 20xx
DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
Noble-metal-free NiFe nanoparticles immobilized on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions for highly efficient hydrogen production from hydrous hydrazine Hongtao Zou, Qilu Yao, Meiling Huang, Meihua Zhu, Fei Zhang, Zhang-Hui Lu*
Hydrous hydrazine (N2H4·H2O) has been considered as a highly promising liquid chemical hydrogen storage material because of its high hydrogen content (8.0 wt%), simple byproduct (i.e., N2) and safe handling. In this work, noble-metalfree NiFe nanoparticles (NPs) supported by nano CeZrO2 solid solutions have been facilely synthesized and successfully applied as a highly efficient catalyst for the rapid and complete decomposition of N2H4 in aqueous solution. The turnover frequency (TOF) value of NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst for hydrogen generation from N2H4 reached 119.2 h−1 under alkaline condition at 343 K, which is 28-fold higher than that of the benchmark catalyst pure NiFe NPs (4.2 h−1). Moreover, the H2 selectivity and activity almost have no decline after five runs, indicating that the prepared NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst possesses high durability and stability under the current conditions. The high catalytic performance can be attributed to the synergistic electronic effect between NiFe NPs and nano CeZrO2 solid solutions, as well as small nanoparticles with high dispersed active sites.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogen has been widely recognized as one of the most promising and sustainable energy carrier because of its high gravimetric energy density and environmentally benign nature.1-3 However, the storage and transportation of hydrogen has become one of the most significant challenges for the human society.4,5 Thus, the search for safe and efficient chemical hydrogen storage materials to conveniently release hydrogen under mild conditions is desired urgently.6-8 Hydrous hydrazine (N2H4·H2O) is an ideal hydrogen carrier because of its high hydrogen content (8.0 wt%) and high stability as well as generation of only N2 as byproduct besides H2 via eqn (1) in the presence of suitable catalysts. In this respect, selective decomposition of N2H4 in aqueous solution has received much attention.9,10 However, to maximize the efficiency of N2H4, the undesired decomposition to ammonia (eqn (2)) should be avoided.11,12 Therefore, the key is to develop efficient and selective catalysts for hydrogen generation from N2H4.
N2H4(l) → N2(g) + 2H2(g) (1)
3N2H4(l) → 4NH3(g) + N2(g) (2)
In recent decades, many noble-metal-containing Ni-based heterogeneous catalysts have been recognized as the efficient
catalysts for dehydrogenation of N2H4 (e.g., RhNi,13-16 PtNi,17-20 IrNi,21-23 PdNi,24-27 etc.), but the potential application of them are limited by their high costs. Therefore, developing the noble-metal-free catalysts to replace precious-metalcontaining catalysts for this reaction is highly desirable. In 2011, Xu's group first reported the noble-metal-free bimetallic NiFe nanoparticles (NPs) stabilized by CTAB for hydrogen evolution from N2H4 in aqueous solution at 343 K. 28 Up to now, some non-noble-metal catalysts have been reported for selective dehydrogenation of N2H4.29-38 However, the kinetics of these catalysts is very sluggish. Therefore, the development of low-cost catalysts with high-performance is needed for the practical use but still remained a challenging.
In order to control and stabilize the size of metal NPs, organic agents (e.g., polymers, surfactants) are widely used, but the active sites of metal NPs' surface may be blocked by surface ligands, which is unfavourable toward the catalytic reactions. 39 So, inorganic supports, such as active carbons,40-41 silica42-44 and metal oxides6,37 are widely applied as supports of nanocatalysts. Among them, ceria-based metal oxides showed promising selectivity and activity for dehydrogenation of N2H4 due to their high stability and redox properties.29,35,36,45-47 Furthermore, compared to pure CeO2, doping the transition metal oxides such as Y2O3, ZrO2 and TiO2 into the CeO2 could adjust the synergistic structural and electronic effects.48-50
In this work, noble-metal-free NiFe NPs were successfully immobilized on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions support without the help of surfactant by a simple impregnation-reduction approach. Unexpectedly, the resultant NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst exhibited the superior catalytic activity and 100% H2 selectivity

sections.heading: Materials and chemicals
sections.text: Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Aladdin, 99.95%), lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, Aladdin, 99%), neodymium nitrate hexahydrate (Nd(NO3)3·6H2O, Aladdin, 99.9%), zirconyl chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O, Macklin, 98%), poly (ethylene glycol)-block-poly (propylene glycol)block-poly (ethylene glycol) (Pluronic 123, Aldrich), iron sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4·7H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., 99%), nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O, Aladdin, 99.9%), cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O, Aladdin, AR), copric chloride dehydrate (CuCl2·2H2O, Aladdin, 99.99%), silica gel (mSiO2·nH2O, Aladdin), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Vetec, average mol wt 360,000), Vulcan XC-72R carbon black (Cabot), aluminum oxide (Al2O3, Aladdin, 99.99%), hydrous hydrazine (N2H4·H2O, Aldrich, 98%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent, >96%), sodium borohydride (NaBH4, Aldrich, 99%) and absolute ethanol (C2H5OH,Tianjin Zhiyuan Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR) were used as received. All reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without any purification.

sections.heading: Synthesis of catalysts
sections.text:
The CeZrO2 solid solutions were synthesized according to an Evaporation-Induced Self-Assembly (EISA) method reported in the previous work.51-53 The NiFe NPs immobilized on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions were prepared by a simple liquid impregnation-reduction method at room temperature. Typically, for the synthesis of Ni0.8Fe0.2/Ce0.9Zr0.1O2, 100 mg Ce0.9Zr0.1O2 was dispersed in 8.0 mL H2O and sonicated for 10 min to get a fully dispersed suspension, then 2.0 mL of aqueous solution containing NiCl2·6H2O (0.16 mmol) and FeSO4·7H2O (0.04 mmol) was added into the suspension. The resulting suspension was continuously stirred for 4 h to impregnate the metal salts into the cage of Ce0.9Zr0.1O2. Finally, 50 mg NaBH4 was used as a reducing agent and added into the above suspension solution to obtain Ni0.8Fe0.2/Ce0.9Zr0.1O2 catalyst. The synthesis of NixFe1-x/Ce0.9Zr0.1O2 (x = 0, 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.9 and 1.0) catalysts with different Ni molar content is following the analogous process. The final compositions of Ni/Fe in the NixFe1-x/Ce0.9Zr0.1O2 catalysts were analyzed by ICP-OES (Table S1). A series of Ni0.8Fe0.2/Ce1-xZrxO2 catalysts with different Ce/Zr ratios can be obtained using this method. Except where otherwise noted, the NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst discussed below is nano Ce0.9Zr0.1O2 solid solutions-supported NiFe NPs with a Ni/Fe molar ratio of 8/2.
NiFe/CeZrO2 catalysts with different metal loadings (7.7 wt%, 9.3 wt%, 11.6 wt%, 15.5 wt%, 23.2 wt% and 46.5 wt%) were synthesized using the above method by changing the
quality of the CeZrO2 (150 mg, 125 mg, 100 mg, 75 mg, 50 mg and 25 mg).
For comparison, NiFe NPs supported on different carriers, such as SiO2, PVP, Vulcan XC-72R and Al2O3 were synthesized by a similar method. In addition, NiCo/CeZrO2, NiCu/CeZrO2, CoFe/CeZrO2 and CuFe/CeZrO2 catalysts were also prepared by the same method.

sections.heading: Characterization
sections.text: The morphology and microstructure were observed and analyzed by a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM2100), a scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM, Talos F200X, FEI, USA) coupled with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured by a Rigaku Rint 2200 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were obtained after Ar sputtering for 300s using an ESCALAB 250XI X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with an Al Kα source. Inductively coupled plasma–optical emission spectroscopy (ICP–OES) measurements were performed on a Varian 725-ES to measure the composition of the catalysts. Specific surface area measurements were carried out by a BELSORP-mini II surface analyzer using nitrogen adsorption/desorption at liquidnitrogen temperature (77 K). The generated gas (N2 and H2) was analyzed using a FuLi GC-9790 equipped with a TDX-01 column connected to thermal conductivity detector (TCD).

sections.heading: Catalytic measurements
sections.text:
Reaction apparatus for measuring the H2/N2 evolution from the N2H4 in aqueous solution was the same as previously reported.16 The catalytic measurements for dehydrogenation of N2H4 were performed directly using the catalyst suspension in a typical water-filled graduated burette system. Typically, a 10 mL of the as-synthesized catalyst suspension in water containing NaOH (2.5 M) were taken in a two-neck roundbottom flask (50 mL), which was placed in a water bath thermostat at 343 K under magnetic stirring. The catalytic reaction was initiated by adding 0.1 mL N2H4·H2O (2.0 mmol) into the flask with vigorous stirring. The gas generated was passed through a trap containing HCl solution (1.0 M) to eliminate the influence of any evolved ammonia (NH3). The volume of H2 and N2 were measured by recording the displacement of the water level in the gas burette. The reaction was completed when there was no more gas generation. The H2 selectivity (α) could be evaluated on the basis of the eqn (3), which could be deduced from the eqn (1) and eqn (2).
3N2H4 → 6αH2 + (2α+1)N2 + 4(1-α)NH3 (3)
As NH3, if generated, is absorbed by aqueous HCl solution in the trap, the gas measured by the burette contains only N2 and H2, which gives the molar ratio (λ) of released gas to hydrazine, i.e., n(N2+H2)/n(N2H4). Therefore, the H2 selectivity (α) could be calculated according to eqn (4).

For the durability test, after the completion of the hydrogen generation reaction, another equivalent of N2H4·H2O (2.0 mmol) was added into the reaction system and the released gas was monitored by the gas burette. The process was repeated for five runs at 343 K.

sections.heading: Catalysts characterization
sections.text:
The morphologies of as-synthesized CeZrO2, NiFe and NiFe/CeZrO2 were characterized by TEM. The nano CeZrO2 solid solutions show spherical nanoparticle morphology with a mean particle size of 5.0 nm (Fig. 1a and 1g), smaller than pure CeO2 (10.1 nm) and ZrO2 (7.7 nm) (Fig. S1). After loading of NiFe, the resultant NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst still keep the same structure as its parent CeZrO2 (Fig. 1b, 1h, Fig. 2 and Fig. S2), indicating that ultrafine NiFe NPs are dispersed on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions. In sharp contrast, the pure NiFe NPs are aggregated to a larger size of about 14.8 nm (Fig. 1c and 1i), which clearly demonstrates that nano CeZrO2 solid solutions could act as the barrier to protect the NiFe NPs from serious aggregation. Besides, the selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of NiFe/CeZrO2 in the insert of Fig. S2b provides a mixed polycrystalline diffraction ring with the indexed planes (111) of NiFe and CeZrO2, indicating the fabrication of composite structure. In Fig. S2d, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst presents the lattice fringes with spacing of 0.202 nm for NiFe (111) planes (red marked) and 0.308 nm for CeZrO2 (111) planes (yellow marked). In addition, the EDX spectra prove the presence of Ni, Fe, Ce, Zr and O elements in NiFe/CeZrO2 sample, and the Cu signals are from the copper grid (Fig. 1d-1f). High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and elemental mapping images of NiFe/CeZrO2 revealed that the elements of
Ni, Fe, Ce, Zr and O are homogeneously distributed in the NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 2).
The crystalline nature of the prepared catalysts was analyzed by powder XRD characterization. Fig. S3 shows the XRD patterns of the nano Ce1-xZrxO2 (x = 0, 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9 and 1.0) solid solutions. The CeO2 showed intense and sharp diffraction peaks of cubic fluorite structure (JCPDS No. 43- 1002). The diffraction peaks shift to higher 2θ angles when the zirconium content is increased, suggesting that zirconium was successfully doped into the ceria lattice structure and the crystal phase of the sample gradually changes from a cubic to a tetragonal structure.49,51,52 Fig. S4 shows the XRD patterns of the as-synthesized CeZrO2, Ni/CeZrO2, Fe/CeZrO2, NiFe/CeZrO2 and pure NiFe NPs catalysts. The diffraction peaks of Ni/CeZrO2, Fe/CeZrO2 and NiFe/CeZrO2 catalysts coincided with the peaks of the CeZrO2 supports of cubic fluorite phase. The peaks of possible Ni, Fe or NiFe species were not found, implying that these species were highly dispersed on the surfaces of nano CeZrO2 solid solutions, consist with the TEM observation (Fig. 1b, Fig. 2 and Fig. S2). To eliminate the disturbance of CeZrO2, pure NiFe NPs were prepared using the similar method as for NiFe/CeZrO2 for XRD detection (Fig. S4), the NiFe NPs have a broad and weak peak at 44.9o, which is between the (111) plane of face-centered cubic (fcc) Ni (JCPDS No. 01-1272) and fcc Fe (JCPDS No. 52-0513), indicating that the NiFe was in crystalline alloy state. The BET surface of CeZrO2 (108.6 m2·g-1) is higher than that of pure CeO2 (16.9 m2·g-1) and ZrO2 (52.2 m2·g-1). Compared with that of pure CeZrO2, an obviously decrease in the specific areas of the NiFe/CeZrO2 (74.2 m2·g-1) is observed, due to the loading NiFe NPs on the surface of nano CeZrO2 solid solutions (Fig. S5 and Table S2).
The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of NiFe/CeZrO2 reveal the existence of Ni, Fe, Ce, Zr and O species in the sample (Fig. S6). As shown in Fig. 3a, both signals of Ce3+ and Ce4+ from the Ce 3d spectra are observed.54 The Ce 3d5/2

peaks at 883.1, 883.6 and 895.4 eV, and Ce 3d3/2 peaks at 899.7, 906.1 and 915.3 eV are assignable to Ce4+. Whereas the Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 peaks at 885.8 and 903.8 eV can be assigned to Ce3+ species. The NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst exhibits two Zr 3d peaks at 182.0 and 184.4 eV that could be related to the Zr 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 (Fig. 3b). The binding energy of Zr 3d in the NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst was higher than that in ZrO2, indicating that Zr acts as an electron donor. 49 As shown in Fig. 3c and 3d, the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks at 852.7 and 870.1 eV for NiFe/CeZrO2 are observed, corresponding to Ni0. Similarly, the signals of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks at 707.3 and 720.4 eV are assigned to Fe0. In addition, the Ni 2p3/2 peaks at 855.2 eV and Fe 2p peaks at 712.4 and 722.0 eV are assigned to the Ni2+ and Fe3+, respectively, which may be attributed to the oxidation of the surface NiFe NPs in air during sample processing.27 Besides, the Ni 2p3/2 peaks at 859.5 eV and Fe 2p3/2 peak at 715.4 eV can be attributed to the satellite peaks, respectively. Furthermore, it can be seen clearly that the binding energies for Ni 2p and Fe 2p in NiFe/CeZrO2 were negatively shifted with respect to those in pure NiFe NPs, probably due to the increase of electron density in the metal centers. In addition, the Ni 2p peaks of NiFe/CeZrO2 slightly shift to higher binding energy compared with that of Ni/CeZrO2, while the negative shift is observed in the Fe 2p levels of NiFe/CeZrO2 compared with that of Fe/CeZrO2, further confirming the construction of NiFe alloy.18,28 Such electronic transport between Ni, Fe and CeZrO2 solid solutions in the NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst might enhance the catalytic activity and H2 selectivity for decomposition of N2H4.55

sections.heading: Catalytic activities
sections.text:
The catalytic activities of the as-synthesized NixFe1-x/CeZrO2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1.0) toward the dehydrogenation of N2H4 were studied in the presence of NaOH at 343 K. As shown in Fig. 4, the molar ratio of Ni/Fe plays an important role in catalytic performance. Fe/CeZrO2 is almost inactive for this reaction, while Ni/CeZrO2
is active with a low H2 selectivity of 76%. All the bimetallic NixFe1-x/CeZrO2 catalysts exhibit higher H2 selectivity than that of monometallic Ni/CeZrO2 and Fe/CeZrO2, which might be mainly attributed to the synergistic electronic interaction between Ni and Fe as revealed by XPS analysis in Fig. 3. The introduction of Ni could promote significantly both the activity and H2 selectivity. With an increase in Ni content (x from 0 to

0.8), the activity of the NixFe1-x/CeZrO2 catalysts increases, showing the maximum turnover frequency (TOF) value of 119.2 h-1 at x = 0.8, and a further increase in Ni content exhibits a negative effect on decomposition of N2H4. The molar ratios of the NixFe1-x/CeZrO2 catalysts were measured by ICPOES, and the analysis results almost identical to those calculated from the initially added materials to prepare the NixFe1-x/CeZrO2 (Table S1). Gas chromatography (GC, Fig. 5) measurements demonstrate the generated gas consists of H2 and N2 (H2/N2 = 2), which means that the as-synthesized NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst has a 100% H2 selectivity for the dehydrogenation of N2H4.
The catalytic performances of the pure NiFe NPs, CeZrO2 and NiFe/CeZrO2 were tested for decomposition of N2H4 (Fig. 6). As for CeZrO2, it is seen that no gas generation was observed, indicating that CeZrO2 is inactive towards the dehydrogenation of N2H4. The pure NiFe NPs can generate 1.6 equivalents of (H2 + N2) in 169.4 min with a TOF value of 4.2 h-1. It is found that the NiFe NPs dispersed on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions leads to a dramatically high catalytic and H2 selectivity (Fig. 6 and Fig. S7). Remarkably, the Ni0.8Fe0.2/CeZrO2 catalyst can release 3.0 equivalents (H2 + N2) (i.e., 100% selectivity) within only 12.3 min with a TOF value of 119.2 h-1, which is 28 times higher than that of the pure Ni0.8Fe0.2 NPs (Fig. 6 and Fig. S7) and comparable to those of reported noble-metal-free catalysts with high activity (Table S3).11,28-38 The optimal dosage of nano CeZrO2 solid solutions is 100 mg (Fig. S7). However, the continuous increasing CeZrO2 would lead to the suppression of the catalytic activity, possibly due to the fact that the active sites of NiFe NPs on the surface were likely to be blocked and/or covered by the excess nano CeZrO2 solid solutions.
Furthermore, the NiFe/Ce1-xZrxO2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1.0) catalysts with different Ce/Zr compositions have been prepared in order to investigate the role of support in the promotion of catalytic performance (Fig. S8). In the presence of the NiFe/CeO2 catalyst, 2.7 equivalents of (H2 + N2) were generated in 33.9 min from the decomposition of N2H4, giving a TOF value of
45.3 h−1. For the NiFe/ZrO2 catalyst, 1.8 equivalents of (H2 + N2) were released in 101.3 min with the corresponding TOF value of 7.8 h−1. It is found that NiFe NPs dispersed on the surface of Ce1-xZrxO2 with a small Zr (x ≤ 0.3) could show enhanced catalytic activity and H2 selectivity (Fig. S8). The optimal x value is 0.1. This could be explained that the introduction of Zr could efficiently change the electronic structure of catalysts as shown by the results of XPS (Fig. 3), and thereby improve the catalytic performance.
Notably, the use of NaOH plays a key role in promoting the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. S9, without addition of NaOH, NiFe/CeZrO2 shows lower catalytic performance with 1.6 equivalents gas released in 23.0 min, giving a TOF value of 30.4 h−1. Clearly, it is found that the addition of NaOH can significantly enhance the catalytic activity and H2 selectivity. NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst shows the best activity and 100% H2 selectivity with 2.5 M NaOH, giving a TOF value as high as 119.2 h-1, which is almost 4 times higher than that in the absence of NaOH (Fig. S9). The possible reason is that the presence of OH− in N2H4 solution could promote the rate determining deprotonation step (N2H4 → N2H3* + H*) while limiting the formation of undesirable N2H5+ ions (N2H5+ + OH− → N2H4 + H2O), which is crucial and beneficial for the elimination of N-H bonds to produce N2 and H2. Additionally, the presence of alkali can also inhibit the release of the basic byproduct ammonia (NH3),11,12,56,57 which can be beneficial to

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
6 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
increase the H2 selectivity for the selective dehydrogenation of N2H4.
For comparison, the LaZrO2 and NdZrO2 were synthesized and used as the support. As shown in Fig. S10, LaZrO2 and NdZrO2 supported NiFe NPs also show excellent catalytic activity and H2 selectivity for the dehydrogenation of N2H4 in aqueous solution at 343 K in the presence of NaOH, and the corresponding TOF values are 100.3 and 103.7 h-1, respectively, showing the universality of the ReZrO2 (Re = Ce, La, Nd) supported NiFe catalyst. The enhanced catalytic activity caused by the addition of different rare-earth oxides may be owing to their similar physical and chemical properties. In addition, to study the key effect of CeZrO2, the NiFe NPs immobilized on other supports, such as SiO2, PVP, Vulcan XC72R and Al2O3 were also prepared and tested for dehydrogenation of N2H4. As shown in the Fig. S11, their catalytic performances are all inferior to that of NiFe/CeZrO2, suggesting the key factor of nano CeZrO2 solid solutions in facilitating catalytic performance. Moreover, our preparation is not limited to NiFe but can be extended to other non-noble catalysts. NiCo, NiCu, CuFe and CoFe NPs supported on CeZrO2 were also prepared by the same method as NiFe/CeZrO2. As shown in Fig. S12, CuFe/CeZrO2 is inactive. CeZrO2 supported NiCo, NiCu and CoFe NPs exhibit a lower selectivity than that of NiFe/CeZrO2.
The hydrogen release rate of the NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst strongly depends on the reaction temperature. The TOF values of 24.7, 54.5, 119.2, 188.5 and 236.8 h−1 were obtained at 323, 333, 343, 353 and 363 K, respectively (Fig. 7a). The values of rate constant k at different temperatures were calculated from the slope of the linear part of each plot when the conversion reached 50%. From the Arrhenius plot of ln k vs 1/T (Fig. 7b) for the NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst, the activation energy (Ea) was determined to be 50.4 kJ·mol-1, which is much lower than that of pure NiFe NPs (76.3 kJ·mol-1, Fig. S13). Furthermore, the catalytic performances of the synthesized NiFe/LaZrO2 and NiFe/NdZrO2 catalysts were also measured at different reaction temperatures (323-363 K). The corresponding Ea were estimated to be 68.9 and 57.4 kJ·mol-1, respectively (Fig. S14
and Fig. S15), which also lower than NiFe NPs (Fig. S13), indicating that ReZrO2-supported NiFe NPs can decrease the activation energy and improve the kinetics property for selective dehydrogenation of N2H4. In addition, it is found that the prepared NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst possesses excellent stability for dehydrogenation of N2H4 (Fig. 8). The H2 selectivity of NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst is retained over five cycles while the reaction rates show a slight decrease. Meanwhile, NiFe/CeZrO2 after recycled test was separated and characterized by XRD and TEM. There are no obvious changes in size and structure of NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst (Fig. S16), which further confirms that the NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst possesses high stability under the current conditions. The durability of NiFe/LaZrO2 (Fig. S17) and NiFe/NdZrO2 (Fig. S18) were also evaluated, and the results suggest the good durability of these catalysts.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, noble-metal-free NiFe NPs were successfully immobilized on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions without the help of surfactant by a simple liquid impregnation-reduction method at room temperature. The characterization results revealed that ultrafine NiFe NPs were homogeneously dispersed on nano CeZrO2 solid solutions. By virtue of synergistic effect between NiFe NPs and CeZrO2 support, the as-synthesized NiFe/CeZrO2 catalyst showed superior catalytic performance (TOF, 119.2 h-1), 100% H2 selectivity and good stability toward the selective dehydrogenation of N2H4 in aqueous solution. In addition, the NiFe NPs dispersed on LaZrO2 and NdZrO2 also exhibited excellent catalytic performances and good durability for the selective dehydrogenation of N2H4. As a consequence, the highly efficient NiFe/CeZrO2 can be considered as a candidate to replace noble metal catalysts for this reaction, which may promote the practical application of N2H4·H2O for chemical hydrogen storage.

sections.heading: Conflicts of interest
sections.text: There are no conflicts to declare.

Graphical abstract
Noble-metal-free NiFe nanoparticles were successfully immobilized on nano CeZrO2
solid solutions without surfactant by a sequential impregnation-reduction method,
which exhibited high catalytic activity and 100% H2 selectivity for hydrogen
generation from hydrazine (N2H4).
